REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS 5 Report of State Auditor State of Nebraska AUDITOR'S OFFICE To Hon. Charles W. Bryan, Governor of Nebraska My dear Sir: In accordance with Statute 4847 I take pleasure in submitting my report herewith, covering the period from July 1, 1922, to June 30, 1924. The balance sheet of the State, as required by Statute 4847, appears on Page 10, showing Resources as of July 1, 1924, amounting: to $66,626,334.80, with no State indebtedness. The receipts and Expenditures are shown for the two separate fiscal years, from July 1, 1922, to June 30, 1923, and from July 1, 1923, to June 30, 1924, respectively. Government Cost and Revenue Receipts The question is often asked: "How much does it cost to run the State?", and "What are the revenues of the State?" In this report I have undertaken to answer these questions compre - hensively by calculating the averages, and refer to "Comparative State - ment No. 2, appearing on fage 44, wnere tne Government Costs and the Revenue Receipts of the State of Nebraska are given for the years 1922, 1923 and 1924. The following shows the averages per year: Government Cost payments — average for last 3 years Current State Revenues, including General Property and Business Taxes, Non-Business Taxes, County Road Moneys, Office and Inspection Fees, Receipts at State Institutions, etc., represent broadly speaking the revenues collected under the taxing and police power of the State. The other classes, Contributions from U. S. Government and Income from Trust Fund Holdings, will need no explanation. Amounts collected on matured investment bonds, State lands sold, and receipts to revolving funds for material sold, representing a mere change of assets, are not included, being classified as Non-Revenue Re - ceipts. So also are classed the receipts to the Hail and Bank Depositors Guarantee Fund, which represent private funds, disbursed tinder State Ordinary Operating Expenses $ 6,988,375.40 Capital Outlay and Public Improvements 4,743,495.14 Disbursement of Temporary Trust Funds 1,096,026.55 Total $12,827,897.09 Revenue Receipts — average for last 3 years Current Revenues $10,982,071.00 Contributions from U. S. Government 1,415,094.52 Income from Trust Fund Holdings 1,103,592.01 Total _ $13,500,757.53 13,500,757.53

6 REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS Supervision. Similarly the corresponding expenditures being classified as Non-Government cost, have not been included. The current revenues (Taxes) reached the peak during the year 1922, when a higher tax had to be levied to provide for the Soldiers' Relief Bonds ($2,000,000.00) to be purchased from tax moneys. The operative expenses were highest in 1923, amounting to $7,074, - 430.10. But this included the expenses of the biennial Legislative Ses - sion, amounting to $168,812.90, which is not a regular annual expense. If this be deducted, bringing the 1923 Ordinary Expenses down to $6,905,557.20, then the erpenses for the fiscal year ending June 30, 1924, would be the highest. Thus during the last three years the Ordinary Expense shows a slight increase, while the Capital Outlay shows a great reduction for the year 1924, as illustrated by the following: Unfortunately it is not possible to extend the comparison back further than 1922, the fiscal year having been changed in 1921, and former Auditors not having classified and tabulated the receipts and expenditures by years. Also, prior to the passage of the Gerdes law in 1911 (Statute 4900 and 4901), many of the so-called cash funds were not handled by the State Treasurer. Departments would examine and inspect, collecting fees for the work and depositing same in a bank. Then they would pay the salaries and expenses by checks drawn against that bank. Such ex - penditures, therefore, would not be reported as State expense. Now all such collections are paid into the State Treasury and the expenses are paid by State warrants, thus increasing the reported State's revenues, as well as the expenditures It is, therefore, not possible off - hand to make comparisons of present day State expenditures as against those of earlier years. Bonds Issued by Subdivisions During the last two years bonds issued by subdivisions were regis- Fisca ear Ordinary Expenses $7,O00,O00.(K $e,ooo,oco.o( Public Improve- ments and Capital Outlay $5,0U0,000.0( I L . $4,000.000.0(

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS 7 tered by the State Auditor, amounting to $24,718,084.79. This repre - sents a slight reduction as shown by the following: Period Bonds Registered Av. per month Indebtedness of Subdivisions An effort has been made by my Department to accurately ascertain the amounts of bonded indebtedness of the various subdivisions of the State. County Clerks have been requested to furnish statements of the bonded indebtedness of their county or of municipalities, or districts, etc., within their county, in accordance with Statute 289. On the basis of such reports and the records of the State Auditor, Statements No. 9 and No. 11 have been compiled. The figures are believed to be substantially correct for most counties. Some of the counties appear to have kept no records during the earlier years, and the bond records of former State Auditors in some cases are found faulty also. I hope that the authorities of the various counties, municipalities or districts will scrutinize the figures shown in this report, and notify this Department of any discrepancies so that the record may be completed or corrected. In my former report I suggested that a registration fee of 10c be charged for each bond registered, to be paid into the State Treasury and the amounts so paid be made available for the payment of the expenses of the Bond Department. I repeat my recommendation. To avoid placing additional burdens upon the tax-payers, those issuing bonds should pay the cost of registration. Uniform System of Accounting In accordance with Statute 4975 I have established a "Uniform System of Accounting for County Treasurers." A manual containing detailed instructions was sent to every County Treasurer in the State abount October 20th, 1924. The object, outside of complying with the law which requires the State Auditor to establish uniformity, is to be helpful to County Treas - urers, to facilitate the work of the State Examiners, and to make manipu - lations difficult; also there will be a saving to the tax-payers since the use of standard forms to be procured from blankbook houses will avoid the expense of having costly books ruled and printed. County Treasurer Examinations The law providing for two County Treasurer examiners was passed in 1893. Since then several new counties have been established, the population and wealth of the State has increased, and many new duties have been laid upon the County Treasurers, such as collecting auto ve - hicle licenses, increase in paving, drainage, irrigation, etc., taxes, pay - ing bonds and coupons, all of which more than doubles the work of the State Examiners. The work is still being done by two examiners, ex - cept that in some difficult cases the State Accountant has been called in. More effective methods of examinations have been introduced, and we are trying to make the very best examination with so limited a force. The Uniform System of Accounting will facilitate the work of the ex- 24 Mo. Dec. 1, 1916 to Nov. 30, 1918 $ 7,651,488.10 24 Mo. Dec. 1, 1918 to Nov. 30, 1920 _. 22,124,089.52 19 Mo. Dec. 1, 1920 to June 30, 1922 24,567,318.00 24 Mo. July 1, 1922 to June 30, 1924 24,718,084.79 $ 318,953.0< 921,837.01 1,293,016.01 1,029,920.01

REPORT OF AUDITOR OF PUBLIC ACCOUNTS 8 aminers, but for best results the force should be increased, so that time could be taken for a more extended examination. Confirmation of Appointment* The Statutes (4848 — eleventh) provide: " the auditor of public accounts shall, with the ap - proval of the governor appoint an expert accountant, whose entire time shall be devoted to the service of the state as directed by the auditor " Subsequent to the enactment of this Statute, the Civil Administra - tive Code Departments have been established, same being under the direct control of the Governor. Since the duties of the State Accounting Department include auditing the Governor's Code Departments, the ap - pointment of the State Accountant should not be made subject to the approval of the Governor, and I therefore suggest that the above Statute be amended. GEO. W. MARSH, Auditor of Public Accounats. State House, Lincoln, Nebr., July, 1924.
